{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3351311,"name":"Jack ","username":"harmony6","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/90db22/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-03T13:21:41.399Z","cooked":"

We have been trying for a couple of weeks now to tune the PID for our Swerve mk4i steering motors (Neos, L2 ratio) but no matter what they do they still seem to react too slowly. We have seen videos of other teams’ steering motors and they all seem significantly more responsive than ours. We have tried messing with our PID values (especially P as that should make it approach the desired angle faster) but it is always either too slow or extremely unstable.

Eg. We have all four wheels pointing forward, and we send a command to translate left. Instead of immediately going left, the robot makes a wide sweeping turn (radius of a meter or 2) as the wheels slowly align themselves.

Also here is the link to our code: GitHub - team7036/Crescendo

If anyone has any idea please let me know.
Thanks, Team 7036

To be able to debug this effectively, we will need to actually see your code. There could be a number of causes, including different ways you could be capping the power sent to the motors.

Looks like your code is using a trapezoid profile with a max speed of 1 rotation/sec and max acceleration of 1 rps/sec. Try dropping the trapezoid profile (the quickest way to test would be to set those constraints to 10000 and see what happens; if it works, you can rip out the profile logic)

Yes i just saw the same thing they have

            public interface Turn {

                double MAX_VELOCITY = 2 * Math.PI;
                double MAX_ACCELERATION = 2 * Math.PI;

in their constants.

@harmony6 i’d try something higher but still physically attainable, maybe 10.0 for max velo and 40.0 for max accel as a test.

Also i recommend you drop your P value down lower since it also seems a bit high at 9.0.
